captions.text:
Ah, spring is in the air, the daisies are
in bloom, the mild April breeze is bringing

the sweet smell of rotting flesh that emanates
from the vacant lot full of disinterred corpses
that the winter snows once mercifully preserved.

Which is as good an explanation as any for
why so many fucking remasters have come out
this month.

So if you&#39;re one of those idiot millennials
who think Halo 1 counts as a &#39;retro&#39; game

then there&#39;s never been a better time to educate
yourself in a couple of old classics and start

the long, slow, difficult road to becoming
a tolerable human being.

Having said that, some of the &#39;old classics&#39;
on display this month are playing a bit fast

and loose with the definition of the word
&#39;classic&#39;.
And, for that matter, &#39;old&#39;.

Bayonetta&#39;s just been re-released on Steam
and I&#39;ve got skidmarks in my underpants that
are older than Bayonetta.

Although fair&#39;s fair, this wasn&#39;t so much
a remaster as a port, PlatinumGames finally

bringing an old console exclusive to PC in
accordance with the basic law of the universe

that all matter must eventually gravitate
towards a point of maximum sensibleness.

A better example would be the Bulletstorm:
Full Clip edition, that actually does posture

itself as a &#39;remastering&#39; and not merely a
port to Steam.

Which is just as well, since vanilla Bulletstorm
was already on Steam or rather had been before
this thing showed up.

But hey, it&#39;s only by getting the Full Clip
edition that you can have the original intended

Bulletstorm experience, by which I mean, pay
full price for it.

Besides that you&#39;re getting a graphical improvement,
but it was only one generation ago so it&#39;s

the kind of graphical improvement that&#39;s like
hanging a slightly nicer chandelier over an
orgy.

And there&#39;s a new mode where you can play
through the game as Duke Nukem.

I&#39;m guessing Duke Nukem was the only one to
return their phone calls.

Because I can&#39;t imagine the Bulletstorm devs
sitting down and saying &quot;Right, who can we

add to our game who embodies in our audience&#39;s
minds success, high quality and having a realistic
understanding of one&#39;s value and capabilities?&quot;
&quot;How about Duke Nukem?&quot;
&quot;What an excellent suggestion, Crispin.
Let&#39;s go with that.

Obviously I&#39;m being sarcastic, and since it&#39;s
so obvious I&#39;m going to omit this sentence
from the official transcript of this meeting.&quot;

&#39;&#39;
But anyway, let&#39;s move on to remasters of
games that are actually both old and classics.

Such as Full Throttle Remastered, a scene-for-scene
remake of the classic Tim Schafer adventure

now with a pixel resolution that doesn&#39;t make
all the characters look like they&#39;re having
their identities protected.

&#39;Cos he&#39;d already done that for Grim Fandango
and Day of the Tentacle so the only one left
to do was the dodgy one.

Tim Schafer has stated that Full Throttle&#39;s
shorter length makes it a better fit for 2017

audiences, a surprisingly candid statement,
effectively saying &quot;What a relief that everyone&#39;s
standards are so much lower these days.&quot;
No, that&#39;s not fair.
Full Throttle is by no means a bad game.

It&#39;s a fun, fluffy little yarn about the leader
of a biker gang in a proto-Mad Max near future

battling evil industrialists, the voice cast
is basically a Batman the Animated Series

reunion, and really how can one not admire
a point and click adventure game whose standard

commands are not &#39;Look, talk, use&#39; but &#39;Look,
talk, use, kick in the bollocks&#39;.

Unfortunately the metaphorical monkey on Full
Throttle&#39;s back - or perhaps I should say

&quot;Monkey Island on its back&quot; - is that it has
to be compared to the other classic LucasArts

adventure games, among which it would be the
runt of the litter if it weren&#39;t for The Dig

staggering around on its one functional leg
leaking on the carpet from every body part
that can leak.

I never had a problem with Full Throttle&#39;s
length, it was more that most of the gameplay

was shit, so complaining about the length
would be like complaining about someone vomiting

on your pie because they could only manage
two heaves.

Story traditionally steers the adventure game
motorbike while gameplay sits behind to offer

the occasional reach-around, but for some
reason Full Throttle is obsessed with breaking

things up with arcade minigames, most annoyingly
the bike combat that&#39;s like trying to play
Cookie Clicker while riding a unicycle.

But even disregarding those, the puzzle design
just isn&#39;t up to the usual classic LucasArts
standards.

Where in Monkey Island you&#39;d get puzzles that
balance cleverness, good writing and world

building, like the insult swordfighting business,
Full Throttle has a prolonged puzzle centred
around staring at a crack in a wall.

Perhaps there&#39;s an inherent issue with making
an adventure game, traditionally a more thoughtful

genre about characters who can&#39;t brute force
their way through situations, about a dude

who uses brute force like it&#39;s a brand new
Soda Stream that he&#39;s trying to convince himself
wasn&#39;t a waste of money.

It makes me wonder why we suddenly have to
craft some artful means of distracting the

souvenir stand man when smashing people&#39;s
faces into the dirt has been so reliably fruitful
thus far.

&#39;&#39;
So let&#39;s move onto another new remaster, Planescape

(hurgh) Torment (hurgh) Enhanced Edition,
a CRPG popularly considered to be one of the
best of its kind.

Full disclosure, I can&#39;t confirm because I
can only ever play Planescape Torment for

about an hour before the combat gets too much
for me.

Not the combat-combat, which is a load of
sticky bollocks on a cold serving tray, I&#39;m

talking about the relentless battle I find
myself in with the fucking text window as

it remorselessly disgorges endless spiked
sub-clauses and paragraphs and conversation

trees with more branches than Wells fucking
Fargo.

I&#39;ve heard Planescape Torment described as
&quot;the best book you&#39;ll ever play&quot;, but sadly

I&#39;m not a book critic, &#39;cos you need actual
qualifications to be one of those.

I like games, with narrative woven into gameplay,
and only prefer books when I&#39;m in specific
sorts of moods, you know?

Like when I&#39;m on a long haul flight, or when
both my thumbs have been pecked off by crows.

But hey, I fully admit to having a low attention
spa - oh I&#39;m bored of this sentence, let&#39;s
talk about something else.

The last remastering I&#39;d like to bring up
this week is perhaps the definitive example

of ageing poorly, second only to a fruitbowl
in direct sunlight.

I give you: Parappa the Rapper remastered
on PS4.

Which some people seem to remember fondly,
but which looked to me like a string of cutscenes

that couldn&#39;t be enlarged beyond native PS1
resolution and as such you could miss entirely

if a medium-sized fly lands on your TV screen,
broken up by a total of six gameplay sections

consisting of the crumbs of gameplay that
fall off a modern game if you hold it upside
down and shake it vigorously.

I thought I&#39;d like this since I can hold my
own at Guitar Hero and the principle of &#39;press

the button when we say so&#39; is one that the
last ten years of triple-A combat engines

has been keeping me well practiced in, but
the rhythm in this rhythm game is being monitored
by a narcoleptic mountain goat.

I could not for the life of me get past the
fifth stage.

I pressed the buttons when it said to but
the game wasn&#39;t having any of it.

Then experimentally I tried playing as awfully
as I thought I could get away with and somehow
that had a slightly better success rate.

One of us clearly has something badly wrong
with them, Parappa the Rapper, and I know

it&#39;s not me because I got my test results
back from the STI clinic.
What the fuck do you want?

If you tell me to crack, crack, crack the
egg against the bowl one more time I&#39;m going

to crack, crack, crack your head against a
plinth.
